articles.headline: Rand Paul, Warning About Spying, Faults Obama
articles.snippet: Senator Rand Paul, in a speech at Berkeley, injected the issue of race into the debate over domestic surveillance by saying President Obama should be wary given the government’s history of eavesdropping on civil rights leaders.
articles.abstract: Senator Rand Paul, in a speech at Berkeley, injected the issue of race into the debate over domestic surveillance by saying President Obama should be wary given the government’s history of eavesdropping on civil rights leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, said Wednesday that President Obama should be particularly wary of domestic spying, given the government’s history of eavesdropping on civil rights leaders like the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., injecting the issue of race into the contentious debate over surveillance.

articles.headline: Administration Plays to Young in Health Push
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is taking its mission to radio shows, churches and YouTube to urge people to buy health insurance ahead of the March 31 deadline.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is taking its mission to radio shows, churches and YouTube to urge people to buy health insurance ahead of the March 31 deadline.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russian troops were rolling through Crimea when Denis R. McDonough, the White House chief of staff and a foreign policy expert, was deployed on a mission to do media outreach. But the focus of Mr. McDonough’s calls to local talk radio stations was not geopolitical tensions in Eastern Europe, it was health care.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Tanzina Vega

articles.headline: Traders of Tips Meet at Grand Central, and Eat the Evidence
articles.snippet: The government’s case against two Wall Street insiders laid bare an elaborate if somewhat old-fashioned plan, where a middleman would relay tips, written on a Post-it note or napkin, at Grand Central Terminal’s four-faced clock.
articles.abstract: The government’s case against two Wall Street insiders laid bare an elaborate if somewhat old-fashioned plan, where a middleman would relay tips, written on a Post-it note or napkin, at Grand Central Terminal’s four-faced clock.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:40 p.m. | Secret stock tips scribbled on Post-it notes and paper napkins. Illicit meetings held in broad daylight at Grand Central Terminal. Cover-up efforts that involved chewing, and even eating, damaging evidence.

articles.headline: Discovering Two Screens Aren’t Better Than One
articles.snippet: A once-confirmed two-monitor user decides to turn off one screen and learns how to battle the temptation of email and YouTube.
articles.abstract: A once-confirmed two-monitor user decides to turn off one screen and learns how to battle the temptation of email and YouTube.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, techies have argued that getting an extra monitor or two for your desktop computer is an especially effective way to increase personal productivity. The logic seemed airtight: Two (or more) computer monitors means more room on your virtual desktop, which means more room to do your work. And more room to work would seem to mean faster work.

articles.headline: Fed Cuts Bond Buying by Another $10 Billion
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve also signaled its intention to keep short-term interest rates near zero after the unemployment rate falls below 6.5 percent
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve also signaled its intention to keep short-term interest rates near zero after the unemployment rate falls below 6.5 percent
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve further curtailed its economic stimulus campaign on Wednesday, even as it said the effort would continue for the foreseeable future given the enduring consequences of the Great Recession.

articles.headline: Two States Win Court Approval on Voter Rules
articles.snippet: The federal Election Assistance Commission had denied requests from Kansas and Arizona to add proof-of-citizenship instructions to registration forms.
articles.abstract: The federal Election Assistance Commission had denied requests from Kansas and Arizona to add proof-of-citizenship instructions to registration forms.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — A federal judge in Kansas on Wednesday ordered federal election authorities to help Kansas and Arizona require proof of citizenship of registering voters, in a decision that could well set a trend for other Republican-dominated states.

articles.headline: Placing Their Bets on Bitcoin
articles.snippet: A growing field of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has put Hong Kong on the edge of something big.
articles.abstract: A growing field of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has put Hong Kong on the edge of something big.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — By day, David Shin is an investment banker at a major financial firm. By night and in pretty much every other free minute, he is an entrepreneur looking to break into Hong Kong’s growing Bitcoin scene.

articles.headline: Wooing a New Generation of Museum Patrons
articles.snippet: Museums are preparing for the eventual passing of the baton from the baby boom generation, which has long been the lifeblood of giving and boardroom leadership.
articles.abstract: Museums are preparing for the eventual passing of the baton from the baby boom generation, which has long been the lifeblood of giving and boardroom leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several hundred millennials mingled under the soaring atrium of the Guggenheim Museum on Fifth Avenue one recent frigid February night. Weaving around them were black-clad servers bearing silver trays piled high with doughnuts, while a pixieish D.J. spun Daft Punk remixes.

articles.headline: New Insights Into History May Skew the Big Picture
articles.snippet: History — the fullest, richest story we can tell about ourselves and our past — may be beyond the reach of most museums, however much they try.
articles.abstract: History — the fullest, richest story we can tell about ourselves and our past — may be beyond the reach of most museums, however much they try.
articles.lead_paragraph: Museums are born to wrestle with history. What else, after all, is a museum but a collection of objects gathered to shape a narrative, to assert an interpretation, to evoke memory and reaction — in other words, to make a history? So when I complain, as I often do in making my critical rounds, about the way history is treated in museums, how could it be otherwise? History — particularly in nonart museums — is the point. And it is bound to be an issue of debate.

articles.headline: Door to Art of the World, Barely Ajar
articles.snippet: When it comes to telling an inclusive story of art, small museums in the West, as well as those in Africa and Southeast Asia, often do a much better job than the largest institutions.
articles.abstract: When it comes to telling an inclusive story of art, small museums in the West, as well as those in Africa and Southeast Asia, often do a much better job than the largest institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a pay-what-you-wish Saturday evening in late February, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum rotunda was dense with visitors to a new show, “Italian Futurism, 1909-1944: Reconstructing the Universe.“

articles.headline: In Hong Kong, Placing Their Bets on Bitcoin
articles.snippet: A growing field of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has put Hong Kong on the edge of something big.
articles.abstract: A growing field of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has put Hong Kong on the edge of something big.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — By day, David Shin is an investment banker at a major financial firm. By night and in pretty much every other free minute, he is an entrepreneur looking to break into Hong Kong’s growing Bitcoin scene.

articles.headline: Tempered Cheers in Ukraine for Ex-Premier, Tied to Political Past
articles.snippet: Yulia V. Tymoshenko, recently released from prison, has emerged as a pivotal, if not beloved, figure in a nation that finds itself directly astride the East-West divide.
articles.abstract: Yulia V. Tymoshenko, recently released from prison, has emerged as a pivotal, if not beloved, figure in a nation that finds itself directly astride the East-West divide.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Released from prison last month by the rebellious Ukrainian Parliament, Yulia V. Tymoshenko raced to Independence Square in Kiev to join the celebrations. But the appearance of Ms. Tymoshenko, a former prime minister, was curiously subdued, and not just because she was in a wheelchair.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: A Mystery: Who Are the Dewey Secret Seven?
articles.snippet: Some lawyers wonder whether the district attorney agreed to any sweetheart deals with the seven unnamed cooperators who might have avoided jail, or pleaded to a lesser charge instead of a felony.
articles.abstract: Some lawyers wonder whether the district attorney agreed to any sweetheart deals with the seven unnamed cooperators who might have avoided jail, or pleaded to a lesser charge instead of a felony.
articles.lead_paragraph: They are the mysterious seven: former employees of Dewey & LeBoeuf who pleaded guilty to taking part in a four-year plan to manipulate the financial statements of the once prominent law firm, but whose identities and plea agreements are being kept under wraps by New York prosecutors.

articles.headline: Paying Price, 16 Years Later, for an Illegal Entry
articles.snippet: A man’s deportation case previews the difficulties President Obama will face in a review he ordered last week, asking the Homeland Security secretary to come up with a more “humane” policy.
articles.abstract: A man’s deportation case previews the difficulties President Obama will face in a review he ordered last week, asking the Homeland Security secretary to come up with a more “humane” policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The cellblock intercom awoke Josue Noe Sandoval-Perez at 1 o’clock on a frigid January morning at a detention center in northwest Missouri: Get your things, get ready to go. Immigration officials were preparing to whisk him away.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Damien Cave

articles.headline: Bloomberg Hints at Curb on Articles About China
articles.snippet: Comments from the chairman of Bloomberg L.P. represent the starkest acknowledgment yet by a senior Bloomberg executive that the ambitions of the news division should be assessed in the context of the business operation.
articles.abstract: Comments from the chairman of Bloomberg L.P. represent the starkest acknowledgment yet by a senior Bloomberg executive that the ambitions of the news division should be assessed in the context of the business operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The chairman of Bloomberg L.P. said in a speech here on Thursday that the company should have reconsidered articles that deviated from its core of coverage of business news, because they jeopardized the huge sales potential for its products in the Chinese market.
articles.byline: By Neil Gough and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Sexual Misconduct Case Ends With No Jail Time for General
articles.snippet: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair, who pleaded guilty to mistreating his mistress and other charges, will not serve time in prison.
articles.abstract: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair, who pleaded guilty to mistreating his mistress and other charges, will not serve time in prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N.C. — Bringing an end to a closely watched military sexual misconduct trial, a judge on Thursday reprimanded Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair for, among other offenses, mistreating an Army captain who was his mistress, but did not sentence him to jail time and allowed him to remain in the military.

articles.headline: Corporate Lies Are Increasingly Immune to Investor Complaints
articles.snippet: A recent court ruling in Germany, along with a pending case before the United States Supreme Court, could make it harder for investors to recoup damages tied to company fraud.
articles.abstract: A recent court ruling in Germany, along with a pending case before the United States Supreme Court, could make it harder for investors to recoup damages tied to company fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: Companies do not have a right to lie to their shareholders, a German judge ruled this week. But sometimes, she added, lies are necessary.

articles.headline: New Capital Could Raise Airbnb Value To $10 Billion
articles.snippet: The couch-surfing company is close to raising more than $400 million in a new round of financing, which could give it a valuation of more than $10 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday.
articles.abstract: The couch-surfing company is close to raising more than $400 million in a new round of financing, which could give it a valuation of more than $10 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Airbnb is poised to join the 11-digit club.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Obama Steps Up Russia Sanctions in Ukraine Crisis
articles.snippet: President Obama also opened the door to more sweeping measures against core parts of the Russian economy, including the oil and natural gas industries.
articles.abstract: President Obama also opened the door to more sweeping measures against core parts of the Russian economy, including the oil and natural gas industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama expanded sanctions against Russia on Thursday, blacklisting a bank and several wealthy businessmen with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin, as the United States struggled to forestall further Russian incursions into Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Annie Lowrey and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: In Iran, Hopes Fade for Surge in the Economy
articles.snippet: Confronted with a lack of funds, President Hassan Rouhani has little option but to take steps that will increase the pain for the voters who put him into office.
articles.abstract: Confronted with a lack of funds, President Hassan Rouhani has little option but to take steps that will increase the pain for the voters who put him into office.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Suffering in an economy dragged down by years of mismanagement and the effects of international sanctions, Iran’s increasingly impoverished middle class voted in huge numbers last summer for President Hassan Rouhani, who promised to reignite growth by restoring ties with the rest of the world.
